so what is pollumi hulumi is a modern infrastructure as code tool what that means is that you can use
polomi to provision and manage cloud native infrastructure using real programming languages we support all the major cloud providers as
well as on-prem and the languages we provide and support are javascript typescript python
go and net and why are languages important when you're managing your infrastructure well for a couple of reasons for one as the
industry has kind of shown the appeal to mutating state on a machine is not the most declarative way
to manage infrastructure we've moved to a model where we're really trying to manage states in an api based system that's a
little bit more programmatic that's a little bit more tameable and you can you can reconcile those differences pretty easily
that's very much how kubernetes works with languages the real appeal to it is that as folks adopt their cloud native
infrastructure as operators and developers expand this architecture this architecture can become complex and
managing this really becomes unwieldy so programming languages allow you to leverage the ability to have a full
turing complete machine essentially right that allows you to use imperative code to drive declarative state and this allows you to not only
manage the complexity of your infrastructure but it also allows you to technically change uh the properties and
see those those changes in your ide because we can code it against a actual spec you can see helpers you can see linters
you can see documentation you can do testing so using programming languages far exceeds how you contain
the complexity of your cloud native infrastructure than other tools in the current space so how does that actually work well let's
look at the snippet in the on the right corner what you see is go code that allows us
to import the libraries from polumi so in polumi we expose all of the cloud providers as well as kubernetes

i can also extract properties from the machine for example such as the ip of its nat so i can share

i usually break down the serverless model into three different components there's

i push something to github to my master branch it will send a push event to my event

and start creating the build process in a pipeline each step is its own container and you can actually use

you can create logic if x is met if y is met move to this step move to that
step and also one necessary uh
function that we see a lot of people are are enjoying is the catalog so while yes you might have edge cases
that are very specific to your use case there are a lot of cases that are very common like building
pushing to kubernetes pulling from github we actually have a catalog of reusable tasks and pipelines that you
can pull in rather than having to reinvent the wheel every time and of course right now it's already

way to deploy uh to to do your ci cd pipelines and kind of your

very security conscious and they don't like to have make calls outside of the cluster or outside of their environment
in order to pull code so having it all in cluster is
a nice little benefit so now we're going to move on from tecton and talk a little bit about
k native k native isn't really so much of a product so to speak as much
as it is the building blocks for you to build a serverless kubernetes
so you might be thinking well what's serverless kubernetes did we manage to get rid of node pools and node requirements well no
but we're talking about the developer perspective from the developer perspective what it does is it abstracts the common tasks
that you will see from the kubernetes api and make it make it very simple for a
user to deploy auto scale route traffic to their to the new service that they deploy it's
an abstraction on top of kubernetes it is not a replacement of kubernetes it is using kubernetes objects
and resources so at the end of the day it's running containers everything's a container everything's in a pod
everything can be extended or integrated with other kubernetes products and of course it's a fully open source
product but what is k native not it is not a google product we did open google did open source it back in 2018
uh but it is not an exclusive google product it is 100 open source we do have a lot of developers but we also have developers
from other organizations that are contributing and we if anybody is interested in continuing to help us
with this contribution that would be great and it is not functions as a service
which i want to reiterate for people who are familiar with thinking serverless equals functions as a service
it is not that it gives you the tools to build that within your own
environment or build up a pass in your own environment so if i'm the operator if i'm the infrastructure
manager using pollumi to deploy my environment and manage the infrastructure
i am and i want to enable my developers to do what they do better i create a pass for
them and make it easier to manage so they can handle their deployments without having to necessarily talk directly to the
to the ops team k native is actually created of two components
uh but you know just to reiterate developers can deploy us directly on it operators can put a level of abstraction
and then of course your platform architects your team that is actually building out the
the component can go ahead and create their own
heroku app engine they're basically their own pass or fast system that can be used internally
